# Draft:Andrew Warfield

Andrew "Andy" Warfield is a Canadian computer scientist, entrepreneur, and technology executive. He is a Vice President and Distinguished Engineer at Amazon Web Services (AWS) and an adjunct professor in the Department of Computer Science at the University of British Columbia (UBC). His work spans distributed systems, virtualization, and large-scale storage infrastructure.
Education and early work
Warfield earned a  in Computer Science from the University of Western Ontario, an  from the University of British Columbia, and a  from the University of Cambridge, where he contributed to the Xen hypervisor project. Earlier in his career, he held research and engineering roles at AT&T Research, Nortel Networks, and Intel Research.
Academic career
After completing his Ph.D., Warfield joined the faculty at the University of British Columbia, where he led research in virtualization, distributed storage, and fault tolerance. His group developed several influential systems, including Remus, Parallax, and Tralfamadore, and his publications have been cited more than 20,000 times. He has served on program committees for leading systems conferences such as SOSP, NSDI, and FAST, and has received both a Sloan Research Fellowship and a Canada Research Chair in Systems and Security for his contributions to computer systems research.
Entrepreneurship and industry
Warfield co-founded XenSource, the company that commercialized the Xen virtualization platform, which was later acquired by Citrix Systems. He later co-founded Coho Data, a Vancouver-based company that developed scale-out enterprise storage systems.
He subsequently joined Amazon Web Services, where he serves as Vice President and Distinguished Engineer, leading large-scale data and storage initiatives, including Amazon S3.
Recognition and publications
Warfield has published extensively in computer systems and storage research and holds over 100 patents. His work has influenced both academic research and commercial cloud infrastructure. Representative publications include:
* Bornholt, J.; Joshi, R.; Astrauskas, V.; et al. "Using lightweight formal methods to validate a key-value storage node in Amazon S3." In Proceedings of the 28th ACM Symposium on Operating Systems Principles (SOSP), 2021.
